ygData.msgSnippet: ... I m under the impression Seth meant don t send levels to the mailing list rather than don t send levels via e-mail ... If I made a new level (which I
ygData.rawEmail:
X-Digest-Num: 16
Message-ID: <17248.16.47.959279670@...>
Date: Sun, 14 Feb 1999 18:51:23 -0500
From: Cookie <cookie@...
Subject: Re: ???

>From: "Sven Lederhogen" <jokercheese@...>
>
>Who made up that rule that we can't send levels to each other??? THIS IS 
>A GLADIATORS MAILING LIST FOR GODS SAKE!!!!!Aren't we suppose to send 

I'm under the impression Seth meant "don't send levels to the mailing list"
rather than "don't send levels via e-mail"...

If I made a new level (which I won't, because I'm no creative genius) then
I'd most likely post the URL to the ML, and whomever wanted to download it
could.

If you want someone to e-mail you some home-made levels, they should be
allowed to e-mail them to you...

... unless, of course, ALL Gladiator levels are copyrighted by FSGames...
in which case, it's my understanding that we wouldn't be allowed to make
levels.

So DO NOT attach levels to e-mails to the ML (they'll probably be kicked by
onelist.com anyways)... but you SHOULD be allowed to post URLs of your
levels, and you SHOULD be allowed to ask for levels via e-mail if you're
willing to take the possibility that the levels are actually viruses in
disguise. Then again, the same 'levels could be viruses' argument could be
applied to nearly every game/file on the internet...

Of course, a VIRUS needs to be EXECUTED. If you don't "run" the program
(ie: gladiator.exe) then it CANNOT infect your computer.

Simple logic applies: If you recieve an executable file (.exe, .com, .bat)
from someone, you should _NOT_ run it unless you know who sent it, and WHY
they sent it.

If I were to distribute levels via e-mail, I would most likely leave them
UNCOMPRESSED (ie: NOT make them into that giant .exe file -- whatever it's
called, i'm too lazy to look. ^_^) so that people KNOW that they aren't
executable.

That's my opinion.
-Cookie
